title: How to Make a Watercolor Cake

steps.headline: Bake three round layers from a cake mix.
steps.description: Or, use your favorite recipe for homemade goodness. Any flavor goes. Either stick to one or mix and match. They are all delicious.

steps.headline: Remove the finished cakes from the tins and allow to cool on wire racks.
steps.description: Remember to line your baking pans with wax paper or parchment that you've greased and floured for easy removal from the pan.

steps.headline: Mix the buttercream frosting.
steps.description: Make a lot. In a large mixing bowl, whip the butter and vanilla until it is light and fluffy with an electric mixer or by hand. Add the powder sugar and milk. Beat until fluffy.

steps.headline: Assemble small containers, cups for example.
steps.description:
Place a heaping tablespoon of frosting in each one. Color each frosting with a different color using liquid or paste food coloring. You can get two shades from all the basic colors by adding slightly more coloring to the second batch; for example, red equals pink and red. Greens can be varied by using more color in one or adding a touch of yellow to give yellow-green. Shades of blue can be achieved varying the amount of blue coloring. By mixing red and blue coloring you can make purple. Mix the colors well using plastic knives, one for each color. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/03\/Bottlesofcolor.jpg\/460px-Bottlesofcolor.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/03\/Bottlesofcolor.jpg\/760px-Bottlesofcolor.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Fill the cakes with buttercream frosting.
steps.description:
Or, put between the layers pudding that you make from a mix by reducing the amount of liquid slightly to give it more body. Build a dam around the outside of each layer with a row of buttercream. This holds the filling in place as the cake is stacked and makes for a clean cut. Keep it simple or be creative by mixing and matching fillings, for example, vanilla all the way, lemon between two layers and blueberry in the remaining one. Take care and stack the layers evenly. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Fillinginplace.jpg\/460px-Fillinginplace.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Fillinginplace.jpg\/760px-Fillinginplace.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":364,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":601.980198019802,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Frost the sides of the cake with while buttercream frosting.
steps.description: Smooth the icing by running a table knife around it while turning the cake. Aim to make it as flat as possible. Frost the top of the cake.

steps.headline: Make it into a watercolor cake.
steps.description: Apply dots of the various color buttercream frostings using the plastic knives that go with each one. Dot colors randomly keeping the colors separate. When all sides have colored dots use a table knife to blend the colors into the base. Try not to muddy the colors by overmixing. Use a light hand and gentle strokes.

steps.headline: Frost the top of the cake.
steps.description: Continue with the abstract pattern you made on the sides. It is lively enough to stand as is, but add more decorations if you please.

steps.headline: Allow the cake to set for an hour before cutting.
steps.description: Refrigerate to set the whole thing. If it is for a birthday, the candles will add a finishing touch.

steps.headline: Enjoy the surprise you've given your assembled cake eaters.
steps.description: Enjoy the praise you will get by doing such a creative project, but don't let on how easy it was.

text:
Preparing the Cake and Buttercream Bake three round layers from a cake mix. Or, use your favorite recipe for homemade goodness. Any flavor goes. Either stick to one or mix and match. They are all delicious. Remove the finished cakes from the tins and allow to cool on wire racks. Remember to line your baking pans with wax paper or parchment that you've greased and floured for easy removal from the pan. Mix the buttercream frosting. Make a lot. In a large mixing bowl, whip the butter and vanilla until it is light and fluffy with an electric mixer or by hand. Add the powder sugar and milk. Beat until fluffy. Assemble small containers, cups for example. Place a heaping tablespoon of frosting in each one. Color each frosting with a different color using liquid or paste food coloring. You can get two shades from all the basic colors by adding slightly more coloring to the second batch; for example, red equals pink and red. Greens can be varied by using more color in one or adding a touch of yellow to give yellow-green. Shades of blue can be achieved varying the amount of blue coloring. By mixing red and blue coloring you can make purple. Mix the colors well using plastic knives, one for each color. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Bottlesofcolor.jpg/460px-Bottlesofcolor.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Bottlesofcolor.jpg/760px-Bottlesofcolor.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Fill the cakes with buttercream frosting. Or, put between the layers pudding that you make from a mix by reducing the amount of liquid slightly to give it more body. Build a dam around the outside of each layer with a row of buttercream. This holds the filling in place as the cake is stacked and makes for a clean cut. Keep it simple or be creative by mixing and matching fillings, for example, vanilla all the way, lemon between two layers and blueberry in the remaining one. Take care and stack the layers evenly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Fillinginplace.jpg/460px-Fillinginplace.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Fillinginplace.jpg/760px-Fillinginplace.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":364,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":601.980198019802,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Frosting and Decorating Frost the sides of the cake with while buttercream frosting. Smooth the icing by running a table knife around it while turning the cake. Aim to make it as flat as possible. Frost the top of the cake. Make it into a watercolor cake. Apply dots of the various color buttercream frostings using the plastic knives that go with each one. Dot colors randomly keeping the colors separate. When all sides have colored dots use a table knife to blend the colors into the base. Try not to muddy the colors by overmixing. Use a light hand and gentle strokes. Frost the top of the cake. Continue with the abstract pattern you made on the sides. It is lively enough to stand as is, but add more decorations if you please. Allow the cake to set for an hour before cutting. Refrigerate to set the whole thing. If it is for a birthday, the candles will add a finishing touch. Enjoy the surprise you've given your assembled cake eaters. Enjoy the praise you will get by doing such a creative project, but don't let on how easy it was.
